Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Relation of Exhumation to Lithsopheric Architecture Along a Steep Continental Margin, Idaho-Oregon
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to determine the link between topographic uplift, erosion and exhumation, pre-existing geologic boundaries, and the underlying mantle dynamics that drive deformation. The field area is the Salmon River suture zone of western Idaho, which is the boundary between Precambrian North America underlying most of Idaho and younger (Phanerozoic) accreted terranes of the Blue Mountains in Oregon. The Idaho batholith formed exclusively on the North American side of this boundary. Post-collision and ongoing deformation affect different parts of the region differently, representing differences in pre-existing geologic structure and/or in deep driving forces. The timing, rates, and amounts of uplift of the various mountain ranges will be related to the current subsurface geometry -- determined using seismic data -- to identify motions in the Earth?s crust and mantle that elevated topography on regional scales. The work entails a combination of seismic data analyses, to provide a detailed sub-surface architecture, and thermochronology, to determing the timing of uplift and exhumation of rocks from depth and the development of the current topography.

The work spans three main study areas and includes a final project synthesis: 1) Documentation of the exhumation path of the Atlanta lobe of the Idaho batholith to determine if it was uplifted by younger magmatism; 2) Evaluation of potential differential exhumation along the trans-Challis fault zone that cross-cuts the Idaho batholith; and 3) Documentation of exhumation in the Blue Mountains, in order to compare its history to that of adjacent North America. A particular focus is whether the Salmon River suture zone was reactivated by post-Columbia River Basalt extension. The combination of the thermochronology and seismic results with recent geology, geochronology, and geochemistry studies will allow synthesis of a regional tectonic evolution and can illuminate the relationship between inherited lithospheric structures and active tectonic processes.

Two graduate and two undergraduate students at the University of Florida and Virginia Tech are directly supported by this work. Tectonic synthesis will involve graduate students at all three institutions, several of whom are funded by other sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Major goal of this project was to understand the relationships - if any - between extant topography in the region of the Idaho Oregon (IDOR) Passive Seismic Project (roughly, northeastern Oregon and the entirety of central Idaho - see the Figures), and crustal structure as defined by passive seismic means. This project builds directly on results of a passive seismic deployment carried out between 2010 and 2013, which saw the installation of 85 broadband stations for two years in an area that spanned a former Mesozoic active margin of western North America (and Laurentia, before that).

We determined crustal structure beneath the Idaho-Oregon study area using telseismic receiver functions recorded at the 85 temporary IDOR broadband seismic stations. We also developed a refined digital elevation model of the region and ground-truthed it using handheld GPS data we collected, based on our observations of a clear change in geomorphology from areas of high topography dissected by deeply incised river valleys and a large contiguous area of high topography that was relatively flat and undissected by fluvial erosion. The seismic network crossed this high topographic plateau in central Idaho (see the Figures), allowing good resolution of crustal thickness, which attains a maximum for the study region of around 42 km. There is a clear relationship between the thick crust and the high topographic plateau. We also examined Bouguer gravity data for the western U.S., including the study region, and we find that the high plateau and thick crust region in central Idaho are also marked by relatively low Bouguer gravity anomalies, consistent with a thickened and elevated crust. We postulate that the central Idaho high plateau is a remnant of a late Mesozoic-early Cenozoic high orogenic plateau that once existed west of preserved Laramide High topography in Idaho, Utah, Nevada and Arizona. The one-time existence of such a plateau has been hypothesized on the basis of geologic observations and arguments since the mid-1980's. However, it is commonly believed that Basin and Range extension since the Miocene has destroyed the high topography and its associated thick crust. We believe the Idaho remnant plateau has escaped this fate.
